channel.title: String regex
channel.description: I'm doing a little bit of work, I got a question. If I wanted to exclude all letters using a string regex: "([a-zA-z0-9])". How can I exclude certain letters? I.e, I want to exclude, I and N. Could I do this? "([a-hj-mo-zA-hJ-mO-z0-9])"

@T41 wrote:

Read up on regular expressions (a theoretical computer science topic), from there learn the regex implementation you plan on using. Most of them are very similar. There’s tons of help online.

item.title: String regex
item.dc:creator: @matzie matzie
item.description:
@matzie wrote:

moparisthebest.com

moparisthebest.com

programming, irc, cars


Should be what your looking for (: My code is at the bottom, its pretty straight forward.

Example:
Base.toString(123,10,“0123456789”);
will return String:“123”
converting an integer(base10) to a String of base-10;(specified by second argument)

Base.fromString(“bz31z”,36,“0123456789abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz”); returns :20112695(int)
for this the second argument(36) is the base of the string of which you wish to convert.
you may put your numbers/letters in any order as a way to “encode” your value and it is not limited to just numbers and letters, you can use any char but it [size=24pt]IS CASE SENSITIVE[/size]

If your base specified is larger than the String length in the 3rd argument, an InvalidArgumentException will be thrown specifying why the error occurred.

also:
Base.fromString(“abc”,“10”,“abdefghijk”);
will throw the exception because (char)‘c’ is not found in the list.

Read full topic
